story:
Leg-a-manjaro 2014

6 climbers from different backgrounds, different challenges, and different experiences are coming together in January of 2014 for one shared goal: to climb to the summit of Mt. Kilimajaro. 

  • 6 Climbers
  • 4 Legs
  • 1 Summit (19,341 feet).

This all disabled ascent of Mt Kilimanjaro is a dream of lead guide Matt Walker and disabled athlete Ronnie Dickson. Together, after supporting disabled athletes learn to rock climb, they shared a vision of supporting an all disabled athlete team to the summit of the tallest mountain in Africa.  

The Inner Passage Foundation is a non-profit 501c3 organization. Your funding is tax deductible and you will receive a tax statement from the foundation for your records.

This is a substantial undertaking and we need your support every step of the way.

What We Need & What You Get

To date we have raised $14,546. In plain terms, We need an additional $30,000. This covers all of the expenses, logistics, equipment, and airtravel for all of the participants. 

We need your support to make this trip a reality for the athletes and their families. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for the athletes to not only go on this expedition, but to join a team of all disabled athletes to climb to the summit.

We are offering a variety of perks for all levels of support:

  • Personal dedication prayer flags on the summit of Kilimajaro
  • Team jackets and gear
  • Expedition photo album
  • Post-expedition presentations by team members
  • 2 spaces for supporters to join expedition as fellow team members
  • and more...

The Team

  • Ronnie Dickson - above the knee amputee, left leg
  • Rajesh Durbal - double below the knee
  • Maggi Pivovar- double below the knee
  • Nate Winters - left amputee above knee
  • Hanna Obrien - congenital amputee, left leg
  • Jake Bainter- right amputee above knee

The Impact

This expedition reaches beyond the lives of the team members, it reaches far into the community they live in and yours:

  • Your support creates an amazing once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.
  • Educates and inspires fellow disabled athletes of what is possible
  • Tears down preconceived notions of what life is like with a "disability"

Matt Walker and Inner Passage have run international mountain climbing expeditions for the past 20 years. As a professional rock climber, Ronnie Dickson is spearheading the field of a disabled adventure sports. Together their goal is to support the success of six disabled athletes to the summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro in January 2014 - they need your support to make this a reality!

story:
Consider Haiti is volunteer-run non-profit with one objective - to promote the health and welfare of children in Haiti. 

We concentrate our efforts on four programs:

  • Providing medical care through week-long clinics twice a year, where more than 1,000 children are seen by volunteer medical teams from Asheville, North Carolina. 
  • Empowering community health agents to support families in maintaining adequate nutrition throughout the year. 
  • Helping families raise goats and rabbits to provide sources of sustainable nutrition for their children. 
  • Ensuring that clean water is available to all families by providing effective, easy to use water filters. 

You can learn more at www.considerhaiti.org.

With this campaign, we are raising funds to maintain the walls of the farm where our programs are housed. 

Consider Haiti operates a two-acre farm in Montroix, Haiti, where all of our programs are based. The farm is only 100 feet from the ocean, and the salt in the air erodes the cinder-block walls. We are asking for your help to purchase supplies to repair and maintain the walls. 

What will you get for helping us out? 

  • With a $20 donation, you'll get a Consider Haiti bumper sticker and a personal thank you on our Facebook page!
  • With a $50 donation, you'll get those perks, plus a Consider Haiti pint glass. 
  • With a $100 donation, you'll get everything above, plus a free entry in this summer's Hotter than Haiti 10K in beautiful Asheville, NC. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out: 

  • Email this link to your friends!
  • Share it on your Facebook page!
  • Tweet about it!
  • Or even...make a few phone calls and ask your friends and family to support Consider Haiti. 

 

Update: May 15, 2013

Thank you to all of the amazing folks who have supported the campaign so far! Any funds raised over the $500 needed to repair the walls will go to repairing the well on the farm. Consider Haiti uses water from this well for crop irrigation and watering livestock, as well as giving the public access to clean water for 3 hours each afternoon. Because of damage caused by recent rainstorms, we've had to limit the water we can provide to the public.

So please don't stop donating if you see that we've reached our goal! 100% of all funds donated to Consider Haiti go directly to our programs on the ground.

story:
Thanks to those who contributed. We are eligible for Philips Innovation BigIdea contest finals. 


DEATHS FROM CHOLERA OUTBREAKS

Every year, over 5 million people suffer from Cholera and over 120,000 of them die from this treatable disease. In Haiti alone, almost 10,000 people have died since the 2010 earthquake and more are dying every day. Our project is to save as many of these people from needlessly dying from Cholera. Why do people die from Cholera when a few saline solution IV bags and antibiotic are all that's needed to prevent death from dehydration? The total cost to treat someone suffering from Cholera can be as little as $20.

 

WHY SO MANY DEATHS?

Current IV bags cost only a couple of dollars, but the weight and bulk of pre-filled IV bags makes it costly to ship. Each 1 liter saline IV bags weigh about 2.3 lbs. (38 oz.). In disaster relief efforts, doctors and workers must physically carry supplies to remote areas by foot or on motorcycles thereby limiting the amount of pre-filled fluid bags that they can take with them. Often most NGOs don't bother shipping IV bags to disaster area due to the cost of shipping.

In a nutshell, it's too expensive and inconvenient for the current IV saline bags to reach those who need them the most.

 

WHAT WE ARE DOING

Our mission is to eliminate unnecessary deaths due to Cholera. Cholera is a treatable disease striking areas across the globe where clean water is unattainable, where natural disasters have hit hardest and where supplies are limited. We have developed Maji™, an intravenous (IV) saline bag solution that can be shipped without water and filled at the site of care with any available water source creating a sterile saline solution for the treatment of Cholera patients.

 

INTRODUCING Maji™

 

Maji™ is a standard 0.9% saline solution IV bag that is shipped dry and filled with any local water source to create a sterile solution at the site of care. Maji uses intelligent technology called Forward Osmosis (FO) to create sterile solution for use on patients. Each Maji bag weighs about 2 oz. and is shipped virtually flat. 

Forward Osmosis is a proven technology which mimics how membranes in nature work, including the human body. The FO membrane draws the water molecules from any water source utilizing ultrafiltration to achieve clean, sterile water. When combined with salt, the clean, sterile water becomes a saline solution suitable for IV and injection applications for patients.

The technology associated with FO is already being manufactured for water purification and extreme drinking water applications. At Fosmo Med, we are bringing this revolutionary FO technology to medical applications in an effort to achieve positive social impact.

 

WHAT WE WILL DO WITH THE FUNDS RAISED

The funds we raise through Indiegogo will enable us to produce a large number of Maji™ FO bags, perform critical biological tests and help us prepare for testing needed for FDA submission. We already have several organizations, including Jordan International Aid, ready to test Maji™ FO bags in Haiti and other places around the world affected by Cholera when the bags are available.

Unfortunately, we cannot give Maji™ bags out to the donors as we do have to follow government and medical regulations. However, you can make a huge difference and also participate in helping to save the lives of those affected by Cholera. For larger donations, we will donate Maji™ bags in your name to those who need them through the doctors and workers who are on the front lines in the treatment of Cholera patients. The more you donate, the more bags we can provide for free to these men and women fighting to save lives. 

If we do not reach our goal of at least $50,000, we will continue to seek other sources for funding so we can continue our project. Each dollar counts because the more we collect, the more Maji™ FO bags we can produce and test and the faster we can provide these bags to Cholera stricken patients around the world. 

 

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS PROJECT ON INDIEGOGO?

Why? Simple: we want to help save lives; specifically, we want to eliminate unnecessary deaths from Cholera. We believe that social medical problems, like Cholera, require social action to provide the best solutions. We are confident that we can make a significant difference in the treatment of Cholera and change the current trend of unnecessary deaths.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are interested in helping out with the worldwide Cholera epidemic, please contribute to NGOs, such as Jordan International Aid, The American Red Cross, Doctors without Borders or any number of hundreds of disaster relief groups throughout the world. They can always use volunteers to help with their mission of treating those in need. 

Final point to clarify, Fosmo Med is not a non-profit organization and your contributions are not tax deductible.
story_txt:
Thanks to those who contributed. We are eligible for Philips Innovation BigIdea contest finals. 


DEATHS FROM CHOLERA OUTBREAKS
Every year, over 5 million people suffer from Cholera and over 120,000 of them die from this treatable disease. In Haiti alone, almost 10,000 people have died since the 2010 earthquake and more are dying every day. Our project is to save as many of these people from needlessly dying from Cholera. Why do people die from Cholera when a few saline solution IV bags and antibiotic are all that's needed to prevent death from dehydration? The total cost to treat someone suffering from Cholera can be as little as $20.
 
WHY SO MANY DEATHS?
Current IV bags cost only a couple of dollars, but the weight and bulk of pre-filled IV bags makes it costly to ship. Each 1 liter saline IV bags weigh about 2.3 lbs. (38 oz.). In disaster relief efforts, doctors and workers must physically carry supplies to remote areas by foot or on motorcycles thereby limiting the amount of pre-filled fluid bags that they can take with them. Often most NGOs don't bother shipping IV bags to disaster area due to the cost of shipping.
In a nutshell, it's too expensive and inconvenient for the current IV saline bags to reach those who need them the most.

The technology associated with FO is already being manufactured for water purification and extreme drinking water applications. At Fosmo Med, we are bringing this revolutionary FO technology to medical applications in an effort to achieve positive social impact.

The funds we raise through Indiegogo will enable us to produce a large number of Maji™ FO bags, perform critical biological tests and help us prepare for testing needed for FDA submission. We already have several organizations, including Jordan International Aid, ready to test Maji™ FO bags in Haiti and other places around the world affected by Cholera when the bags are available.
Unfortunately, we cannot give Maji™ bags out to the donors as we do have to follow government and medical regulations. However, you can make a huge difference and also participate in helping to save the lives of those affected by Cholera. For larger donations, we will donate Maji™ bags in your name to those who need them through the doctors and workers who are on the front lines in the treatment of Cholera patients. The more you donate, the more bags we can provide for free to these men and women fighting to save lives. 
If we do not reach our goal of at least $50,000, we will continue to seek other sources for funding so we can continue our project. Each dollar counts because the more we collect, the more Maji™ FO bags we can produce and test and the faster we can provide these bags to Cholera stricken patients around the world. 
 
WHY ARE WE DOING THIS PROJECT ON INDIEGOGO?
Why? Simple: we want to help save lives; specifically, we want to eliminate unnecessary deaths from Cholera. We believe that social medical problems, like Cholera, require social action to provide the best solutions. We are confident that we can make a significant difference in the treatment of Cholera and change the current trend of unnecessary deaths.
 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
If you are interested in helping out with the worldwide Cholera epidemic, please contribute to NGOs, such as Jordan International Aid, The American Red Cross, Doctors without Borders or any number of hundreds of disaster relief groups throughout the world. They can always use volunteers to help with their mission of treating those in need. 
Final point to clarify, Fosmo Med is not a non-profit organization and your contributions are not tax deductible.

story:
Raymond's family is a family of 6.

Raymond suffers from epidermolysis bullosa, along with EB Raymond fights numerous complications that come with eb.

He's had numerous hospital stays in just the last year which has left the family in a financial debt.

Raymond Father is the only provider for the family and they are finding it very hard at the moment to cover all the monthley expences. Raymond also has a sibling with autism.

Help the Monroe Family they need our support. Life is not easy when your child fights for his life every day, they need a hand up so lets get in there and give them a helping hand!!

https://www.facebook.com/raymond.monroe.71?fref=ts

https://www.facebook.com/groups/272633059493218/?fref=ts

 

Here is a little bit about EB this is what Raymond Suffers From.

Epidermolysis Bullosa is a group of genetic disorders that cause babies to be born with extremely fragile skin layers both externally and internally. Collagen fibers that hold our skin layers together are defective or in severe cases, missing altogether. Without these anchoring fibers the slightest rub, mild trauma or even a loving hug can cause the skin layers to separate provoking large blisters and open wounds.  Can you imagine blisters and sores in your throat as you try to swallow? or how difficult even the easiest task is when the layers of skin on your hands or feet have slid over each other and formed them into mittens, trapping your fingers and toes inside.

Babies born with EB are often referred to as the Butterfly Children as their skin can be so fragile it is compared to a butterfly’s wing. The mildest cases cause a life time of discomfort and require care. The most severe cases can be fatal in infancy, or often require regular blood transfusions and throat dilations. Anemia and infections are also common and often serious problems.  The list of complications is endless, even though EB is rare and there is still much to be learnt before we can find a cure.

You can’t grow out of EB as you get older, to date it remains incurable and new mutations are being found all the time.  In recent years adult cases have been reported with healthy, fit individuals suddenly finding their skin is breaking down. It was previously believed that EB was present from birth and couldn’t be developed at a later date. 

The scariest part is that EB babies are often born to parents who have never seen or even heard of the condition. As a rare condition it’s also not uncommon for their Doctors to have never come into contact with EB. This makes correct diagnosis and care an uphill struggle.  If the baby survives and continues to lead an otherwise normal life, EB becomes genetic.  In dominant EB which is inherited from one parent, there is a 50% chance of passing the disorder to children: in recessive EB which is inherited from both parents carry the EB gene but are usually unaffected, the chance is 25%.

It is estimated that there are 5,000 people with EB in the United Kingdom. One in every 50,000 babies are born with some type of EB in the USA , 1000 living with EB in Australia and 500,000 worldwide.

story:
Care about the health and wellness of low-income women of color?

Please help us reach our $10,000 goal by May 31! The funds will fully support the fall class (there are currently 35 women in the spring class!) and will allow us the time and space to seek grant fundung.

 100 Women Who Care is a campaign to fund Take Back the Trail (www.takebackthetrail.com), a project started by UT professor Terri Givens with the money she inherited, sadly, from losing both of her paretns to cardiovascular disease.

Take Back the Trail's mission is to expose women of color in East Austin to the tools they need to improve their health, allowing them to take back their hearts, health and communities. Our 8-week, evidence based program incorporates physical activity, nutrition education, and facilitated group discussions that focus on how participants can identify barriers and establish and maintain a healthier lifestyle. 

We’ve all read about racial and ethnic health disparities and the disproportionate impact that heart disease, stroke, cancer, diabetes and high blood pressure have on minorities. A few telling statistics:

  • African Americans have the highest rates of obesity at 44.1%, followed by Mexican Americans at 39.3%.
  • Compared to whites, diagnosed diabetes rates are 66% higher among Latinos and 77% higher among African Americans.
  • Infants born to African American women are 1.5 to 3 times more likely to die than those born to women of other races/ethnicities, regardless of income and education level.

The causes are a complex mix of community, individual, cultural, and environmental factors. The solutions are complex, too, but we know they must include targeted community-based interventions like Take Back the Trail (TBTT), a local initiative created by athlete, mom, UT professor, and community activist Terri Givens.

Terri started the project with inheritance money after losing several family members to heart disease and stroke. She has funded TBTT entirely out of pocket to date, including two pilot programs in 2012 (both of which yielded valuable data that demonstrate this program WORKS!) and the currently running spring 2013 program, which has more than 30 women participating. Participants from the pilot programs have come back to serve as volunteer mentors, proof that women can make sustainable changes to their health and well-being and inspire others to do the same.

So who else actually cares about East Side women and their health? Can Austin sustain TBTT for the long-haul? We think so! That’s why today we are launching the 100 Women Who Care campaign. The goal is to get 100 women to contribute just $100 each for the $10,000 TBTT needs to finish 2013.  TBTT recently went under the Southwest Key nonprofit umbrella, so all donations are now tax-deductible. The money raised by 100 Women Who Care by May 31, the end of the campaign, will allow TBTT some breathing room to focus on completing the spring program and aggressively seeking grant funding for the future.

Will you join us in contributing just $100 to sustain this life-changing program?

For your donation to be tax-deductible, you can make a check payable to Southwest Key with “Take Back the Trail” designated in the memo/for line and mail it directly to Terri Givens at 110 West 32nd St. Austin, TX 78705. Otherwise, you can make a donation directly on our website at www.takebackthetrail.com.

If you have questions about TBTT, the 100 Women Who Care campaign, or other ways you can help, please call TBTT’s Organizational Development Consultant, Tricia Forbes, at 512.789.2706 or email her at tricia.forbes@gmail.com. Thank you for your support! Together, we can help ourselves and other women survive, thrive, and be there for our families and communities.

Best, The TBTT Advisory Council

Terri Givens, Founder                                    Diana Gorham

Brenda Coleman- Beattie                    Alice Navarro

Hoover Alexander                               Kerry Meath

Sharon Watkins                                   Catherine Robb

Desire Taylor                                      Anita Ashton

Cassandra Medrano                            Yeni Woodall

Bridget Stephens                                 Sonia Gaillard

Ashly Dunn                                        Anne Stevenson

story:
Hey buddy can you spare a dollar?

How many times have you been approached by a stranger asking for some cash? Did you ignore them or maybe you just didn't have any cash to give? 

What if you knew that the money you gave would go to a good cause but you didn't know exactly what it would fund, would you give then? 

 

There are approximately 7,169,003,000 in the world so if just 1% of the world's population gave 1 dollar to a person or organization the total would be $71,690,030!!

 

In the USA there are approximately 316,668,567 if 1% of the US population gave 1 dollar the total would be $3,166,685.67!!

 

Who Cares!?

I want to see just how many people are willing to part with just one dollar with the promise that I will do something amazing with their money!

I won't say what I'll do or when I'll do it but I can promise that I won't do something stupid like make myself a solid gold shirt or burn it on live TV for shock value! 

What I can promise is that what I am planning will make a global impact and I'm serious about that! Also if $500,000 is raised part of the procedes will go to fully stock a Denver, Colorado Food Bank. 

How can I prove what I am saying is true? Well that's the thing I can't it's up to you to believe me or not all I can say is please can you spare a dollar?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If this campaign intrigues you please share it with everyone you know and help give this campaign the global attention it deserves!

story:
This is a picture of me and Dennis. We had never met before this night. You may be thinking, "So what? I meet new people all of the time!" This is different. This picture was taken on a Friday night. At approximately 1:15 on Wednesday before, I received the amazing news that I had been approved to donate a kidney to Dennis, a man with failing kidneys and non-hodgkins lymphoma. Wait...it gets better! I was visiting my mom and sister in Broken Arrow (which is also where Dennis lives and approximately 90 miles from my home). No one knew I was going there as it was a spur of the moment decision. We were going to a late dinner at Louie's; a place where we had never eaten together before. I had been telliing my mom about my recent approval for donation, my nerves, the basics involving the procedure, and my need for God to confirm my decision. I knew that He was in the midst of things, but did not know if I was clearly hearing Him. On my drive over, I prayed, asking God for some sort of confirmation. So there we sat at Louie's. Fifteen minutes into our time there, I looked to my left and in walked Dennis. I knew it was him because I had seen him on Facebook. His smile and his face, and the chills that took over my body, all told me that this was what I needed. THIS was my confirmation! What were the odds that I would be a match for him? We aren't related and I'm much smaller than him. Who knew that I would ever donate an organ? I've never been put under anesthesia...and I'm scared to death of needles! Who knew that we would be in THAT restaurant on THAT night? I went to shake his hand, and he denied my handhsake. Instead I received the greatest hug. Ok God, I get it! 
 
 
So June is the month for Operation Kidney Jump. I like to think of my kidney puting on a parahchute and jumping into his body. What? Don't judge! I may actually see that when I'm all drugged up. "GERONIMOOOOOOOOO!" Sorry. I had to. :) You may think I'm crazy, but I promise I'm not. You see for me, the surgery doesn't come with much financial impact. I will shed some tears, and will no doubt experience some aches and pains, but my bank account will go largely untouched. Dennis and his family will foot my bill and his. They will walk away with medical debt as well as the uncertainty of what the future holds for them. He has cancer. My kidney will help him with one health hurdle, but I can't give enough of me to take away his cancer. What CAN I do to do more? I want to do MORE! I want to cover his bills. I want to relieve him of that monetary stress and enable him to go forward with his family with one less worry. You can join me in making that happen!

 

I don't know where you are financially speaking, and I know there aren't many of us that can pay outrageous medical bills. I DO know that every bit can help Dennis and his family. No money will go to me and my love for shoes and makeup. No money will send my kids to Disneyworld. It will go to something that matters; something that will have a lasting impact on a family's future for generations to come. Because of your support, they will live more! Life is about living and loving one another, so lets show some love to Dennis!

story:
FINAL UPDATE: 

Thank you to everyone who took the time to read and share this campaign. Thank you, most especially, to those who generously donated to Suzanne. She is truly grateful for everything we tried to do for her, and she asked me to do a final post on this campaign wishing everyone a very Merry Christmas and a happy and healthy New Year.

May God bless you and yours.

Many thanks,
Dana

 

UPDATE:  This is the LAST CHANCE for you to help this cancer patient.  She will be tossed out if no one helps her today.  She has no other means to pay her rent.  PLEASE DONATE ANY AMOUNT BEFORE MIDNIGHT TONIGHT!  Once this campaign expires, it's all over for her. 

I have faith in my fellow man.  I believe that there are enough kind-hearted people out there who will want to help this wonderful human being - I just need to make them aware of the disaster that is about to befall her.  If you can't donate, can you please help spread the word?

Thank you and God bless you.

==============================

My best friend, Suzanne, was diagnosed with colon cancer last year. She almost died and had to have extensive surgery, including a colostomy.  She has had to undergo endless testing and treatment since then and now needs another operation. She has no family.  She has not been able to work because she is so ill and she now has nowhere to turn. She has depleted her savings during this long illness paying medical bills and expenses and now she is about to lose her small apartment.  She desperately needs help to pay her rent & utilities and to buy food for the next three months so she can make it through another surgery. To accomplish this, she needs $6,500 as the surgery recovery will require a wound vac and lots of healing time. I would appreciate any help you could provide for her and I pray you can help her where I cannot. God bless you and thank you for reading this campaign.  I know my friend:  she is the most generous person I have ever met.  She has given so much of herself to helping others.  She works on non-profit projects, such as getting clean water to people who need it.  Now it is she that needs the help of others - a strange position for her to be in because she is usually the one doing the helping.  Please help my friend make it through this next operation so she can hopefully beat this cancer and get back to the business of doing what she loves the most:  helping other people.
story_txt:
FINAL UPDATE:  

Thank you to everyone who took the time to read and share this campaign. Thank you, most especially, to those who generously donated to Suzanne. She is truly grateful for everything we tried to do for her, and she asked me to do a final post on this campaign wishing everyone a very Merry Christmas and a happy and healthy New Year.
May God bless you and yours.
Many thanks, Dana

 
UPDATE:  This is the LAST CHANCE for you to help this cancer patient.  She will be tossed out if no one helps her today.  She has no other means to pay her rent.  PLEASE DONATE ANY AMOUNT BEFORE MIDNIGHT TONIGHT!  Once this campaign expires, it's all over for her. 
I have faith in my fellow man.  I believe that there are enough kind-hearted people out there who will want to help this wonderful human being - I just need to make them aware of the disaster that is about to befall her.  If you can't donate, can you please help spread the word?
Thank you and God bless you.
==============================
My best friend, Suzanne, was diagnosed with colon cancer last year. She almost died and had to have extensive surgery, including a colostomy.  She has had to undergo endless testing and treatment since then and now needs another operation. She has no family.  She has not been able to work because she is so ill and she now has nowhere to turn. She has depleted her savings during this long illness paying medical bills and expenses and now she is about to lose her small apartment.  She desperately needs help to pay her rent & utilities and to buy food for the next three months so she can make it through another surgery. To accomplish this, she needs $6,500 as the surgery recovery will require a wound vac and lots of healing time. I would appreciate any help you could provide for her and I pray you can help her where I cannot. God bless you and thank you for reading this campaign.  I know my friend:  she is the most generous person I have ever met.  She has given so much of herself to helping others.  She works on non-profit projects, such as getting clean water to people who need it.  Now it is she that needs the help of others - a strange position for her to be in because she is usually the one doing the helping.  Please help my friend make it through this next operation so she can hopefully beat this cancer and get back to the business of doing what she loves the most:  helping other people.

story:
Hi,

I am Jodie and I am currently studying psychology with the hopes of becoming a clinical psychologist in order to help those suffering from mental illness.

This campaign is very important as part of the funds raised will go towards a project to help tsunami sufferers and those suffering from mental illness. This campaign is extremely important to me as I am extremely passionate about helping those suffering from mental illness as it is something personal to me. Any contributions will help those in Sri Lanka who are suffering from mental illness.

 I need £1,500, with £750 going towards the project £550 will go towards flights, £38 for a visa £50 for travel insurance and the rest spending money.

Having personally suffered from mental illness I can relate to and really help those who are suffering, so this is a worthy cause and something I am extremely passionate about doing.

This project is run by SL volunteers. SL volunteers are a community of international and local volunteers, sharing skills and time to contribute to community development in Sri Lanka. SL Volunteers is a growing organisation that is led by students and graduates.

This project is run in partnership with Samutthàna. Samutthàna are the King’s College London resource centre for trauma, displacement and mental health. Samutthàna was established with the help of a grant from CAFOD by volunteers from the UK-Sri Lanka Trauma Group, the Institute of Psychiatry, King’s College London and the South London and Mauldsey NHS Trust. The main aim of Samutthana is to train and support organisations and individuals to respond to the psychosocial needs of trauma sufferers i.e. tsunami survivors and those who have experienced civil-conflict in Sri Lanka.

I currently work part time as a support worker helping those suffering from mental illness and have excelled in doing so, thus have the experience to help those in Sri Lanka.

I have also volunteered within my community with a charity singing group called Funrazers, in which we successfully raised funds for many worthy causes.

So, for five weeks I will be working alongside clinical professionals in order to help and support those suffering from mental illness. This is an extremely worthy cause so any donation would be extremely appreciated.

 

Thank you for your time!

Many Thanks

Jodie

story:
Hello Everyone,

My name is Dylan Bracken and this is the beginning of my campaign to raise the funds for my much needed top surgery. Although I hope you take the time to read this in completion, I’m going to break it down into sections so that you can find the information you care about the most.

About me:

I currently live in Saint Louis, Missouri. Before moving here a year ago, I lived in Kentucky while
attending the wonderful school of Berea College. There I double majored in Asian Studies as well as Women and Gender Studies. I’m excited about returning to school when that opportunity arises but I currently can’t afford that.

I was born and raised in Taiwan and lived there until I moved to Kentucky at the age of 19. My parents are Pentecostal missionaries in Taiwan and have been there for 30+ years. I love them dearly and although we are now estranged and my beliefs differ from theirs, I completely support their work because I know they are trying to do what is good and true in their minds. That is what I am trying to do as well. Every day, I do my best to live honestly. That simply means genuinely caring about the world around me and doing what I can to lend a hand. In a sense, I haven’t given up the calling to be a missionary that my family instilled in me. I’ve simply broadened the scope to make the love and compassion I express more inclusive and available to all, including myself.

One of the biggest steps towards living a genuine life has been accepting me for who I truly am; transgendered. Basically the body I was born with has never matched with my gender identity. It took a while, but over the summer of 2010 I realized and accepted that I was not just a masculine woman but in fact a man. I’ve never looked back and I couldn’t be happier. I’ve legally changed my name to Dylan Avery Bracken and I began hormone replacement therapy (testosterone injections) on April 3rd of this year. I finally feel like I'm seeing myself for the first time in the mirror (insert song from Mulan here) and as of a couple of months ago, due to changes from testosterone, I pass as male almost all the time.

This Campaign:

If I pass as male almost all the time, why do I need surgery? That is an excellent question for those of you wondering. There are three main reasons.  The first is for my physical health. One of the keys to passing has been binding my chest to hide the fact that I have breasts of a noticeable size. I have been binding for over two years now. Even though I've learned how to breathe properly, the constant constriction (it is much like a corset for the upper torso) is now consistently causing me a great deal of back pain. Some days it is almost unbearable. So physically, it is vital that I get this surgery soon. The second reason is for my emotional health.  Having a contoured, male looking chest is the missing link to the healthy body image I want so badly.  Sure, I wouldn’t mind having a more muscular body but that simply comes down to hard work and dedication. Hitting the gym won’t make my boobs go away.  That last reason is practical. In the state of Missouri, in order for my sex to be legally changed, I must have some type of surgery. I'm looking into federal ways around that law, but it's important for me to be recognized legally as the man I am.

The Money:

I have two wonderful jobs. The first is at Shameless Grounds, a coffee shop with a mission to “provide diverse populations access to a non-judgmental, sex-positive, radically-inclusive gathering place.” It has become my second home. My other job is at MacroSun International, a fair trade business that brings artwork from Southeast Asian communities to Saint Louis. I am financially completely on my own and am still struggling to pay off debt from school and my immigration to the USA. I love my jobs and they help me pay my bills, but I can by no means afford this surgery on my own.

The surgery I am raising $7,000 for is a double incision/bilateral mastectomy.  I've done a lot of research and talked to other men who have had this surgery from different doctors and the budget is always the same.  The costs directly connected to the procedure come to a total of $6,000. The other $1,000 will be used to cover the cost of travel, recovery, and my bills while I cannot work immediately following surgery.  My roommate, Kelly, has agreed to help me document where every dollar donated goes. She works for the city of Saint Louis’ Homeless Services Department and park of her job is to review how housing providers allocate the funds they receive. After the surgery, I will publish the record so that everyone can see the results of their generosity.

I've included some perks because perks are fun. Feel free to redeem something with your donation. If there is something you believe I have to offer that is not listed, message me and we can work out something specific. If you can donate more than the listed amount, it is greatly appreciated. All of the costs assoiciated with the perks will come out of my own pocket and not be deducted from any donations. I wanted to offer more but with my financial situation, I had to keep them reasonable. 

I love talking about my transition and life in general and am more than happy to answer any questions you may have. Feel free to shoot me a message on Facebook or email me at brackenad@gmail.com

 

Thank you again for your time, love, and support.

Sincerely,

Dylan Bracken

 

A handout about what Transgender means:

http://www.apa.org/topics/sexuality/transgender.pdf

My fabulous places of employment:

http://shamelessgrounds.com/

http://www.macrosun.com/

story:
SIZE CHART & MEASUREMENTS LOCATED ON CAMPAIGN PAGE.

 

Ice, Heat & Compression

                                                                                     
 

Designed for athletes who understand their body and want to optimise their performance, in training and competition, through faster recovery. Whether you prefer ice or heat, the recovery cuff does both, and all fully integrated within the gradient compression cuff. PATENT PENDING
 

 

Cuff Measurements


Riixo was founded with one goal: To help people be better.

 

Improve sport recovery and performance.




Reduce pain after injury & prevent it from happening again.


 

 

 

 

No seams: Stronger design & equal gradient compression

The seamless design means there are no weaknesses in the cuff. No pockets, pouches or straps that can rip or tear. This also ensures the compression remains constant - use after use. 

 



 

Custom insulated case

Each cuff comes in a custom designed, insulated, hard shell case which helps keep the cuffs frozen for up to 5 hours.

 


 

 

YOU FOCUS ON YOUR PERFORMANCE, WE’LL FOCUS ON YOUR RECOVERY


 

 

Improve your performance by speeding up your recovery. Reduce muscle soreness and lactic acid build-up so you can consistently train and compete at your highest level.

Train – Recover – Perform

 

 

What the Riixo Recovery Cuff can do

 

 

Compare


We are Riixo, and we want to challenge outdated and overpriced recovery equipment.  Recovery equipment should not be elitist, it must be for everyone. Let’s start the revolution. We want to make high-performance recovery products affordable, easy to use and supported by evidence and we will start with the Recovery Cuff.

 

    

Cuff Temperature Data

Extend the use of the cuff with the double insulated case 

 

 

Features & Awards

 

 

Fitted design for gradient compression


 

Freezes in 2 hours and stays frozen for up to 5 hours

 

 

Heats in the microwave in 15 seconds

 

 

 

 

Founder's Story.

Riixo was founded by Cameron Johnston in 2017 on his return from peace keeping operations with the United Nations working as a physiotherapist. A former professional rugby player, turned physiotherapist, he has two degrees; Sport Science BSc (Hons) and Physiotherapy BSc (Hons).
 

 

In 2007 Cameron fractured his spine whilst playing rugby. After a year of rehabilitation, he dedicated the next 10 years working to help people who found themselves in a similar position. He has seen, first hand, the impact an injury can have on someone through his time in the UK health services, with professional sports teams, and most prominently during his seven years in the British Army.

 


 

Whilst on operations with the United Nations, in South Sudan, his frustrations grew at the substandard equipment available for recovery. With the primary focus being on the high-end manufacturer he routinely saw equipment with a direct dependency on electricity, water and ice as well as a large price tag.
 

 

Cameron returned with one goal in mind, to show the world how it should be done and how it could be done. Recovery from sport and injury is not just for the elite.





3 IN 1

The Riixo recovery cuff can provide heat or ice fully integrated into a cuff that provides calculated gradient compression to the muscles.
 


 

Cool Box



 

Each recovery cuff comes with a custom designed insulated box. This box keeps the cuff cool for up to 5 hours, allowing you to use it on the go.
 

 

Antibacterial Fibre

 

Made with fibres ionised with silver particles to prevent the growth of bacteria.
 

 

Easy To Use



 

Freeze the whole cuff in a domestic freezer or heat in the microwave.


 

Built To Last.


 

Complete unit, no pockets, pouches or straps so there is nothing to rip or tear.


 

What else is in the box 

Wash Bag. 

Designed for the easy cleaning and care of the cuff. 

 

Slip Sleeve

To help you to quickly pull on the compression cuff. This thoughtful extra was developed after feedback from athlete use. 

 

 

Extras

Ice Ball. 

An innovative mobility tool that combines the benefits of cryotherapy and massage for a great new form of recovery. Simply place the Ice Ball in the freezer for two hours to allow up to six hours of uniquely chilled, free-rolling, recovery massage. Its compact size allows you to conveniently target muscle soreness, knots and joint pain.

RRP £24

Indiegogo Price £18 

-25%

 

 

Product development


"I had the idea for the recovery cuff whilst deployed on operations, in Central Africa, with the United Nations. I was working as a physiotherapist providing injury rehabilitation in a field hospital on the edge of the desert.

 



"I have spent three years manufacturing and testing different materials and designs to come up with the perfect solution.  A compression cuff that can be frozen or heated up without the use of a direct electricity source or the need for ice or water.




"I have been involved in every step of the design and testing process. Utilising detailed feedback from demanding athletes, clinicians and patients all over the world.


 

"Everyone involved is excited about the recovery cuff. It has the potential to revolutionise how people recover from sporting exertions and manage injuries at home."

 

 

 

In Production 

 

Production is underway for the first 200 cuffs. We are ahead of our intended schedule; to deliver these at the start of July. 

 

Timeline     

        

 

 

Free Shipping 



We offer free, worldwide, shipping from our office in Edinburgh using a tracked service. Each package is fully insured and you will receive a confirmation email with your order's unique tracking number. 

 

 

The Team

 

References

  1. Boujezza H, Sghaier A, Ben Rejeb M, Gargouri I, Latiri I, Ben Saad H. 2018. Effects of cold water immersion on aerobic capacity and muscle strength of young footballers. Tunis Med.  Feb;96(2):107-112.
  2. Bouzid MA1, Ghattassi K2, Daab W2, Zarzissi S2, Bouchiba M2, Masmoudi L2, Chtourou H2. 2018. Faster physical performance recovery with cold water immersion is not related to lower muscle damage level in professional soccer players. J Therm Biol. 2018 Dec;78:184-191. doi: 10.1016/j.jtherbio.2018.10.001. Epub 2018 Oct 12.
  3. igueiredo VC, Roberts LA, Markworth JF, Barnett MP, Coombes JS, Raastad T, Peake JM, Cameron-Smith D. Impact of resistance exercise on ribosome biogenesis is acutely regulated by post-exercise recovery strategies. Physiol Rep. 2016;4(2):e12670. doi:10.14814/phy2.12670.
  4. Peake JM, Roberts LA, Figueiredo VC, Egner I, Krog S, Aas SN, Suzuki K, Markworth JF, Coombes JS, Cameron-Smith D, et al. The effects of cold water immersion and active recovery on inflammation and cell stress responses in human skeletal muscle after resistance exercise. J Physiol. 2017;595(3):695–711. doi:10.1113/JP272881.
  5. Roberts LA, Raastad T, Markworth JF, Figueiredo VC, Egner IM, Shield A, Cameron-Smith D, Coombes JS, Peake JM. Post-exercise cold water immersion attenuates acute anabolic signalling and long-term adaptations in muscle to strength training. J Physiol. 2015;593(18):4285–301. doi:10.1113/JP270570.
  6. Gregson W, Black MA, Jones H, Milson J, Morton J, Dawson B, Atkinson G, Green DJ. Influence of cold water immersion on limb and cutaneous blood flow at rest. Am J Sports Med. 2011;39(6):1316–23.
  7. Ihsan M, Watson G, Abbiss CR. What are the physiological mechanisms for post-exercise cold water immersion in the recovery from prolonged endurance and intermittent exercise? Sports Med. 2016;46(8):1095–109. doi:10.1007/s40279-016-0483-3.
  8. Peake M. Cryotherapy: Are we freezing the benefits of exercise? Pages 211-213 | Accepted author version posted online: 28 Mar 2017, Published online: 14 Apr 2017
  9. Hohenauer E, Costello JT, Deliens T, Clarys P, Stoop R, Clijsen R.(2019).Partial-body cryotherapy (-135°C) and cold-water immersion (10°C) after muscle damage in females. Scand J Med Sci Sports. 2019 Nov 2. doi: 10.1111/sms.13593. [Epub ahead of print]
  10. William J. Kraemer, PhD et al (2001) Influence of Compression Therapy on Symptoms Following Soft Tissue Injury from Maximal Eccentric Exercise Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy. Published Online:June 1, 2001Volume31Issue6Pages282-290

Each package is fully insured and you will receive a confirmation email with your order's unique tracking number.   The Team References

Epub 2018 Oct 12.

story:
I am a Buddhist. I just got out of rehab. And I am writing about my experience.

A Buddhist Goes to Rehab – my book in progress – takes the lid off of rehab and provides a candid, inside look at how the rehab process works. It literally presents  a day-by-day account of my 10-week experience in an alcohol rehabilitation program.

Along the way, the book chronicles my experiences on the Buddhist path – how I work through my frustrations with AA language, how I transform the recovery process in ways that work for me and how deepening my meditation practice helps my recovery.

There are lots of books about Buddhism. Lots of books about the 12 steps. Even books that make the connection between Buddhism and the 12 steps. But there’s no book like A Buddhist Goes to Rehab! It takes you behind the scenes before the 12 steps even begin.

This book will have an impact on…

People thinking about entering rehab– because it lets you know what’s in store.

People in recovery – because it provides support for both your sobriety and your spiritual path.

Buddhists – because it charts my week-by-week exploration of the Buddhist path.

Therapists – because, seriously, you need to know this!

Your contribution is essential!!!

Your contribution will allow me to focus on my recovery and finish writing the book while the rehab experience is still fresh in my mind.

Here’s what I will accomplish materially:

  • Finish writing and publish my book
  • Market the book with book tours, talks and book signings
  • Maintain my blog to follow up on my experiences after rehab

Here’s what I will pursue spiritually:

  • Deepen my commitment to the Buddhist path
  • Seek the additional training I need to be become a meditation teacher so I can offer online guided meditations for people in recovery.

About  me....

My name is Danae. I've been an educator, a consultant, a landscaper, a mom and a social justice advocate. So far, I've published an academic book and a young adult dystopian novel called Federation City. (Check it out!).

I started on the Buddhist path about five years ago. I am already 20,000+ words into A Buddhist Goes to Rehab. And I am committed to helping Buddhists and non-Buddhists alike understand more about the process of recovering from addiction.

Thank you so much for your support!  May peace be with you!

story:
July 17, 2016: Thank you kindly for everyone's support. If you're interested in donating further, please visit https://riderinstitute.org/pages/donate. Thank you!


UPDATE -June 5, 2016: We have raised over $20,000! Please support our current campaign at 

https://igg.me/at/EndTheVirus

Read recent news about the DRACO Project on Tech Insider.

UPDATE - May 3,2016: We have launched our second campaign on IndieGoGo! https://igg.me/at/EndTheVirus

UPDATE - March 31,2016: We will launch another crowdfunding campaign soon! 

Visit us at RiderInstitute.org!!


DRACOs (Double-stranded RNA Activated Caspase Oligomerizers) are broad-spectrum antiviral candidates developed by Dr. Todd Rider. They have proved safe and effective in treating ALL 18 viruses against which Dr. Rider has tested them in proof-of-concept work. Two different types of H1N1 influenza (flu), four types of rhinovirus (the common cold), two adenoviruses, dengue hemorrhagic fever, and others were among the 18 viruses that DRACOs have successfully treated in human and animal cells and in mice.

Check out the published results in the peer-reviewed journal PLOS ONE.

We are now raising funds to test and optimize DRACOs against the herpesvirus family, which contains many major clinical viruses such as Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1), Herpes Simplex Virus 2 (HSV-2), Cytomegalovirus (CMV), Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV, chickenpox and shingles virus), Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), and Kaposi's Sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV). Depending on funds, we also hope to test and optimize DRACOs against the family of retroviruses, which includes Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Human T-Lymphotropic Virus (HTLV). In principle, the DRACO approach should be effective against virtually all known viruses, or potentially even against new viruses that may appear.


Join the movement to #EndTheVirus! Donate and spread the word -- We need this to go viral!

Previously published on:

       

   

Dr. Rider’s DRACO approach and results have been called “visionary” by the White House (National Bioeconomy Blueprint, April 2012, p. 9), named one of the best inventions of the year by Time magazine (November 28, 2011, pp. 58, 78), and featured on the BBC Horizons TV program (2013).


Dr. Todd Rider invented DRACOs (Double-stranded RNA Activated Caspase Oligomerizers) at MIT. DRACOs are novel broad-spectrum antiviral drugs that have the potential to revolutionize the treatment and prevention of virtually ALL viral diseases. So far, DRACOs have successfully treated 18 viruses in laboratory tests. DRACOs have proved effective against rhinovirus (the common cold), H1N1 influenza (flu), dengue hemorrhagic fever virus, and more.

With more research, DRACOs may be able to Treat ALL VIRUSES and:

 

A DRACO has already proved effective against rhinoviruses (common cold) and H1N1 Influenza (Swine Flu) in mice and human cell tests!

(i.e; Ebola, Avian Influenza (bird flu), SARS, MERS, etc.)

End the suffering and save the lives of those with incurable viruses (i.e; HIV/ Aids, HSV (cold sores and genital herpes), herpes zoster virus (chickenpox/shingles), HTLV, HPV, etc...)

However, research on DRACOs has entered the well-known “Valley of Death”(Source: NY Times), in which a lack of funding prevents DRACOs, and many other promising new drugs, from advancing toward human clinical trials. 

DRACOs may end suffering and save the lives of those struggling with any number of viruses. The development of antibiotics revolutionized the treatment and prevention of bacterial infections in the mid-20th century. 

With your help, we can bypass the Valley of Death and revolutionize the Treatment of Viral Disease. 


By the process of efficiently eliminating only virus-infected cells, DRACOs may be able to permanently cure viral infections that can currently only be controlled.

When tested in human and animal cells, DRACOs have been nontoxic and effective against 18 different viruses, including rhinovirus (the common cold) and dengue hemorrhagic fever (see table below that outlines 15/18 of the viruses. The additional 3 viruses were coronaviruses).

For more information on the results of previous DRACO experiments, see the article published in PLOS ONE.

Still looking for more explanation? Check out this great video!



The ultimate goal is to develop DRACOs as a cure for virtually all viruses. But in order for that to happen, we'll need the following:

Lab Space

UMass Lowell is an option that is available for us.

Equipment


Continued Research and Progression of Trials

All money goes to 501(c)(3) non-profit, SENS Research Foundation, and so all donations are Tax-Deductible.


Currently, DRACOs are in the Valley of Death--the financial and experimental gap between the previously funded National Institutes of Health (NIH) proof of concept experiments and the threshold for convincing major pharmaceutical companies to advance DRACOs toward human trials. This campaign has been set up to raise the funding necessary to bridge that gap. With your assistance, we hope to raise enough funding to test and optimize DRACOs against clinically relevant viruses in human cells. If successful, the results of those experiments should persuade pharmaceutical companies and other major sponsors to commit their own resources to advance DRACOs through large-scale animal trials and hopefully human trials. Without your assistance, DRACOs may never progress further, and their potential to revolutionize the treatment of viral infections may remain unfulfilled.

85% of your donation, less the $0.30 credit card fee on each transaction and overhead costs, will go directly to DRACOs research!

Dr.Todd H. Rider

Dr. Todd H. Rider studied both biomedicine and engineering at MIT, including coursework at Harvard Medical School, and has spent his career inventing novel biotechnology projects by combining molecular and cellular biology tools with a systems engineering approach. After receiving his Ph.D. from MIT, he worked at Aeiveos Corporation on in vitro experiments to test and potentially intervene in the molecular mechanisms of human aging.  In 1997 he joined MIT Lincoln Laboratory and the MIT Center for Cancer Research and invented the CANARY biosensor, which uses genetically engineered lymphocytes to identify pathogens within seconds with very high accuracy and sensitivity. He engineered and demonstrated the first CANARY cell lines, as reported in his widely publicized 2003 Science paper.  Dr. Rider invented the DRACO antiviral approach, designed the therapeutics and experiments, personally conducted many of the in vitro and in vivo experiments, and recruited and supervised a team in carrying out the rest. His DRACO research has been called “visionary” by the White House (National Bioeconomy Blueprint, April 2012, p. 9), named one of the best inventions of the year by Time magazine (November 28, 2011, pp. 58, 78), and featured on the BBC Horizons TV program (2013). He has also invented additional PANACEA anti-pathogen therapeutics, novel high-energy biofuel cells, and other projects.  Along the way, Dr. Rider founded and runs the Science on Saturday program and other K-12 science outreach programs at MIT.

The Marketing Team

Behind the scenes we have been lucky to have the assistance of several marketing professionals and volunteers.

8:45a  

Moto 9

Timeline: How Long is it Going to Take?

The drug approval process is unfortunately long and complicated. What we know is that 4 years (or less depending on funding) will be enough for Dr.Rider to test and collect enough data on clinically relevant herpes viruses that could be used to engage a big pharma company to take DRACOs to human clinical trials!

The chart below shows the duration of the drug evaluation process. Generally drugs can be prescribed after the FDA review. 

Risks & Challenges. The greatest challenge has been securing funding to help DRACO research progress. It is also important to note that while DRACO is based on sound scientific principles and has yielded promising experimental results thus far, the science of life can be very complex and we can offer no guarantee that DRACO research will end with a pill in a bottle for everyone. Without your help, though, we may never find out.

This is your chance, so please donate! You can help to advance the development of a therapeutic that may be effective against almost any viral infection. So please, choose to help push research forward by making a donation. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Not able to make a donation? --That's okay. If you believe in our mission you can still help by spreading the word on your social media.

Copy and paste to Tweet and post on your Facebook!
Join in to #EndTheVirus with @killingsickness http://igg.me/at/EndTheVirus

story:
About Me & Bone Kush

Hi, my name is Jody Held! I'm a Massage Therapist of 27 years. I live in Florida and visit the pool a lot with my friends! Honestly, I originally invented this product for myself because I didn't want to lean on my hands or arms when tanning. I'm very protective of them and taking care of them is really important to me because of my profession.

I searched for a product like this on the web because a rolled towel or pillow were not cutting it and would slip around too much. When I couldn't find a solution to this problem, I designed a prototype and made one of my own! Since then I have shared this product everywhere I go and everyone just loves it. In fact, the more people that I share it with, the more uses we discover for it too.

This campaign is important to me because I will be able to get the first run of Bone Kush manufactured and distributed to all those people who actually NEED it, at the poolside and everywhere else too.
 

What We Need & What You Get

My target for this crowdfunding campaign is $15000. Here’s what we need those funds for and where they will be going…

Firstly, there is an upfront cost of $2800 for tooling & CAD. This creates the manufacturing mould for the product to be mass produced. $9200 will go towards the actual cost of manufacturing and packaging the product in bulk. Then there is a $1000 shipping cost to have the completed and packaged products delivered to a central location where they will be distributed out from.

Lastly, I am not the most tech savvy person. $2000 will fund the ongoing cost of a web master’s support with the technical elements and marketing for this campaign and for Bone Kush. This will enable me to reach more people and in turn the target set for this campaign.

Whether the final target is met or not the funds from this campaign will still go towards the manufacturing, packaging and distribution of Bone Kush.
 

The Impact

Your contribution will mean the world to me because it will help me to finally get this project into the market place. Inventing is my passion and I have other inventions waiting to bust out! Bone Kush is just the first of many that I want to bring to the market and the public. Your contribution to this campaign will also be supporting a female inventor with a patent. This is a really big deal because females hold less than 7% of patents in the USA!
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest obstacle Bone Kush has faced up to this point has been getting the physical product mass manufactured so that I could begin to sell it. My determination to get my product to market and find a solution means that I have successfully found a manufacturer to help me to bring Bone Kush to life! Once this first run of manufacturing is completed and with your support in this campaign, I can begin to show and sell Bone Kush to businesses and at trade shows.

Whatever challenges or obstacles arise, I know am a strong independent woman with an inventor's will to survive and thrive. I continue to grow, learn and immerse myself into the inventor's world, which is a whole new planet for me. It's super fun and frustrating with all the ups and downs of a roller coaster! Yet I keep getting in line for the ride, over and over again. It is not in my nature to give up.

"Find the path or make the path" - that's my motto.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute to this campaign financially or this product is not for you, you can still support me and Bone Kush. Please use the share tools on this page to help spread the word about Bone Kush to others who might benefit from this product. You could purchase a Bone Kush as a gift for a family member or friend who does have a use for one. Thank you for your support, it means the world to me!

You could purchase a Bone Kush as a gift for a family member or friend who does have a use for one. Thank you for your support, it means the world to me!

story:
LD FIT : The Gym

I am Linda Durbesson, Personal Trainer, Fitness Model & soon to be Competitor.

I have a bachelors degree in Physical Fitness and more to the point, I live the lifestyle required to transform your body from an average « Joan or Joe to a Goddess or God". I know what it takes to make not only the 1st step, but the 2nd, on through the next few weeks that prove to be the breaking point as not much results are seen during this time and eventually to the promiseland. My social media & before - after pics speak for themselves. 

I love helping people. I know I can help everyone who reaches out to me. I was once just a normal person, normal body, just doing ok. I wanted more and I took the steps needed and now here I am. This is my life, this is what I do. Anyone who knows me can tell you I live in the Gym LOL.

Contributions are the key to this people helping system. I already do as much as I can IN-PERSON and ONLINE as a Personal Trainer. A facility geared towards a rehabish outlook on the addiction to bad habits, food choices and excuses would allow the residents the environment, staff and tools it takes to learn how to do it themselves so once released back into their world they: 

1. Look Good 

2. Feel Good 

3. Have the knowledge to keep it going 

4. Can spread the word to their loved ones. 

5. May always return for refresher courses via online, app or in person.


$300k is what we need to get this started

LD FIT : The Gym - Building A Dream From The Ground Up

People are better than banks!!! Lets do this together!!! Getting a loan is not easy

We would want to purchase an acre of land, build a full gym with inside and outside features to the excercise & workout worlds available and a residential facility capable of 1 week to 6 month stays. Enough down payment money to get it started is enough, if we exceed our goal and have the ability to buy cash, that is even better. We would also be building the facility to be Solar powered and " Off The Grid " !!! Yeah! You know what that means? We care about getting our planet in shape too!!!

1. Acre of land ( two acres would be even better, ie track, olympic swimming pool, crossfit outdoors, obstacle course, hike & bike trail, Commercial land can cost over a million an acre in South Florida. 

2. Building a facility from ground up - $? 

3. Gym equipment - $ buy or lease? 

Everything depends upon the contributions here whether we can buy or lease and the difference between them both is huge. This is my dream and it will come true, the fundraising part is a learning experience for me right now, if you have any suggestions feel free to let us know.  

I live the gym life, I live for helping people get in shape and feeling better about themselves by reaching their fitness goals. I know this is a for sure winner, imagine husbands or wives leaving for " The Army " and coming back from bootcamp, only its the Fitness Army !!! You feel me? They come back and can spread the lifestyle, become coaches and mentors alike. 

If we do not reach our goal, we are still here everyday doing this, it is our passion it is our lifestyle and we want to make it available to everyone who reaches out for it. We would want to still open a gym by leasing a building, leasing equipment if it is withing reach with what we raise. We will keep trying until we accomplish this !!!The monies would be put to good use via online sponsorships to needy individuals and help The Linda Durbesson Brand become a heavy hitter in the fitness world to be able to continue providing excellent correspondence in person or online. We are creating a clothing line as well and any ideas that make sense will be put to the test. If we do not open the gym and you contribute a large amount and would want a refund just contact us and we will work that out with you no problem.

LD Fit : The Rehab Gym

Your contributions will provide the facility for people wanting to learn how to live their life as a dedicated fitness person, from the time they wake up, to the time they go to sleep and everything that goes along with it. Its one thing to read a book, or watch a video, talk to someone, but to live alongside them, for a week, a month, 6 months.... on the job training is the best knowledge. I would bet this system would franchise out in the near future. 
Look at my story, from being an average young French lady, to a fitness guru. It was a long journey and continues to be, but ask anyone who has accomplished the same feats, it is well worth it. Not knowing where and how to start is what can stop you from ever setting forth on that journey. 
If you are a contributor, make it known to us and we will provide you with an accommodating package to use for whomever you see fit. Don’t just donate money, follow me on my social medias and watch the progress we make. Let's do this!

All In with LD FIT

Set Your Mind & Goals!  It’s The Best Decision You Will Ever Make! Start Today & Help The Movement

Together we cannot fail. A team of knowledgeable Trainers, who live the lifestyle, not just have the job title, will not accept defeat. They will make everyone coming through our doors a winner. We hold ourselves to high standards of dedication to our clients, residents and followers. We treat our business like we do our bodies, and that is something you can see without a doubt. You cannot photoshop a real person. 


Follow the movement, Friend us, Stay connected.

Money isn't everything! For those of you who cannot afford to contribute, give us a like, a follow, a thumbs up!!! We need those numbers too! Getting the word out there that let's everyone know there is a place they can go to get the proper help they have been looking for. Give us your feedback. Use the Indiegogo share tools to help me help you!!! I look forward to doing this with you all.

story:
Research for rare childhood cancers is severely under-funded. The National Cancer Institute allocates just 4% of its budget to children, and this must be further split amongst the 30 or so different pediatric cancers, leaving very little funding for the kids with these rare diseases. Academic research institutions and pharmaceutical companies do not want to pay for research that would only help a small number of people. National Institute of Health funding is getting harder to obtain, and is primarily focusing on the cancers with bigger patient populations.

     While this strategy may make sense from a budgetary standpoint, when you are a patient with a rare disease it can be quite discouraging. Children with these rare cancers are depending on life-saving research that is NOT moving forward due to a severe LACK of funding from traditional sources.

A new funding model is needed:
     Can we, as patients/parents/advocates/friends/families, come together and privately raise funds to directly support research related to these rare cancers? Do we have to depend on traditional funding sources to move promising research forward, or can we, as a network of Wilms patients/families/friends, find ways to do it ourselves? Can we use the crowd-funding platform as a way to get around traditional funding hurdles and move research with rare diseases forward?

I think we can.

     Let's help the Sadelain Lab at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center hire a cancer researcher focused on Wilms tumor. It costs about $100,000 a year to do this. Dr. Michel Sadelain is doing exciting work directly relevant to Wilms Tumor. He is developing an immunotherapy which targets a cell called NCAM1 or CD56. This cell has been shown to mark for the "cancer stem cell" in Wilms tumor, the very "root" of the disease. It is thought that if we can successfully target this cell, we can improve the success of front-line treatments, and reduce the rates of relapsed disease.

My Story:
     I am the parent of a stage IV, diffuse anaplastic, Wilms tumor survivor, Miss Stellablue Woods, age 7. Stellablue was diagnosed at the age of 4, and has been through more medical procedures than most people will experience in a lifetime. Stellablue has a rare version of Wilms Tumor, and her prognosis is not so great. In early 2013, Stellablue went through a stem cell transplant in an attempt to finally cure her of the disease. It became a goal of mine to find and promote new and more promising research and treatment options for Stellablue and the other 500+ kids diagnosed with Wilms tumor every year. The present-day treatments for anaplastic Wilms were falling woefully short of actually saving kids like Stellablue. I saw that new research, new medicines, and new therapeutic strategies were needed in order to provide more promising treatment options for Stella and other kiddos like her.
     In the process of researching Wilms tumor, I discovered a 2013 paper which showed that the cancer stem cell for Wilms tumor was marked by CD56, and that this cell was likely responsible for disease progression and relapse after treatment. In the year or so that followed, I lobbied the Children's Oncology Group, the National Cancer Institute, and a drug company, in support of a phase I clinical trial for a CD56-targeting monoclonal antibody drug conjugate against Wilms tumor and several other childhood CD56-expressing cancers.
     In the process of advocating for this drug and clinical trial, I was introduced to Dr. Michel Sadelain's work with CD56-targeting CAR T-cells, a potent immunotherapeutic technique which also effectively targets CD56. I have shared with Dr. Sadelain my hopes for CD56 and Wilms tumor, and he has agreed that targeting CD56 may have promising implications for the disease. He also notes that while his lab is working on CD56-targeting CAR T-cells, they do not have a researcher focused on Wilms tumor within the lab. If we could find a way to fund a Wilms Fellow at the Sadelain Lab at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, it would certainly speed research directly related to the disease. Dr. Sadelain has proposed a budget of about $100,000 to hire a Wilms researcher. This person (a doctoral fellow) would work in his lab and would apply this research directly to Wilms tumor.
How to Help:
     Currently, there are at least  1,000 of us Wilms tumor families out there, and if we (plus our network of friends) could each donate $100 or $25 or even $1 towards research that may one day save our own (or a loved one's) child we would be able to support this important research. Let's STEP UP where big-government and big-pharma have failed, and show them that it is indeed possible to fund rare childhood cancers!
Financial Transparency:
     So where exactly will the money go? If we successfully raise $100,000, I will give the money to the Sadelain Lab at Memorial Sloan Kettering so they can hire a Wilms Fellow to study how their CD56-targeting CAR T-cells would work against Wilms tumor. This researcher would focus on looking at how the lab's research would be directly applicable to Wilms patients. Our hope is that this researcher would successfully use an immunotherapeutic technique to train the body's T-cells to target CD56, thereby eliminating the cancer stem cell for Wilms tumor. If we can target and eliminate this cell from Wilms tumor, we will likely see more successful front-line treatments, and reduced rates of relapsed disease.
     And what happens if we fail to meet our $100,000 goal? Even if we fall short, we can still directly support research relevant to Wilms Tumor. While we might not be able to fund a full-time Wilms researcher, even small donations can support research labs in various ways. This is a Wilms Tumor fundraiser, so  whether we reach our funding goal, fall short, or (hopefully) surpass it, 100% of the proceeds from this campaign will be donated to research related to Wilms tumor. I will provide a detailed account on this website, my facebook page, and by email, of how this money is ultimately spent to all donors, as well as provide updates to the Wilms tumor community on the status of this research.
Other ways to help:
     If you can't make a financial contribution, you can still help. Do you know any Wilms families or people who might have a connection to childhood cancer? Please share this campaign with your entire network. Projects like this will have a direct, positive impact on children with Wilms tumor, and will have important implications for other CD56-expressing cancers as well.
     Are you a Wilms tumor patient/family? Please share this campaign with your network of friends. Many people want to help, and this research may have direct implications for you or your child.
     Interested in funding Wilms-related research but can't make a direct contribution? Why not have a fundraiser to support this campaign? Get some friends together, have a barbecue, go bowling, have a pumpkin carving party, sponsor a group walk, etc., etc.,  and raise some money for the Wilms tumor children we know and love.
